titleStmt.title: The Nice Valor, or The Passionate Madman1622
titleStmt.author: Middleton, Thomas; Fletcher, John

editionStmt.edition: This early release includes some 500 EEBO-TCP transcriptions of Early Modern plays that have undergone several routines to create an interoperable and algorithmically amenable corpus of Early Modern Drama. Many incompletely or incorrectly transcribed words have been corrected, including obvious printers' errors, but the text has not been proofread word by word. Each word in the text has been identified as a distinct token with its own xml:id and assigned to a lemma, a part of speech, and a standard spelling. Speech prefixes were mapped to unique speaker ID's as "who" attributes of sp elements. elements

respStmt.resp: Incompletely or incorrectly transcribed words were reviewed and in many cases fixed by

respStmt.name: Philip R. Burns

respStmt.resp: With the help of Thomas L. Berger's Index of Characters in Early Modern English Drama Printed Plays, 1500-1660 speech prefixes were mapped to unique "who" attributes of sp elements by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

note.p: "Never printed before, and now published by the authours originall copies"
First folio; includes the plays not hitherto printed, except the Wild-goose chase, which was missing, but recovered and printed in 1652. Cf. NUC pre-1956.
"The Epistle dedicatorie" is signed by John Lowin, Joseph Taylor, and eight others; "To the reader" signed by Ja. Shirley, who is usually regarded as the editor.
For complete contents of this edition, see NUC pre-1956 imprints.
Reproduction of original in Harvard University Libraries.

div.head: The nice valour, or, the passionate madman.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Shamount, welcome; we have missed thee long,
Though absent but two days: I hope your sports
Answer your time and wishes.

sp.speaker: Sham.
sp.l: Very nobly sir:
We found game worthy your delight my lord,
It was so royal.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: I've enough to hear on't,
Prithee bestow't upon me in discourse.

sp.speaker: 1 Gen.
sp.l: What is this gentleman coz? you are a courtier,
Therefore know all their insides.

sp.speaker: 2 gent.
sp.l: No farther than the taffeta goes good coz,
For the most part, which is indeed the best part
Of the most general inside: marry thus far
I can with boldness speak this ones man's character,
And upon honour pass it for a true one;
He has that strength of many merit in him,
That it exceeds his sovereign's power of gracing;
He's faithfully true to valour, that he hates
The man from Caesar's time, or farther off,
That ever took disgrace unrevenged:
And if he chance to read his abject story,
He tears his memory out, and holds it virtuous,
Not to let shame have so much life amongst us;
There is not such a curious piece of courage
Amongst man's fellowship, or one so jealous
Of honour's loss, or reputation's glory:
There's so much perfect, of his growing story.

sp.speaker: 1 Gen.
sp.l: 'Twould make one dote on virtue as you tell it.

sp.speaker: 2 Gen.
sp.l: I ha' told it to much loss, believe it coz.

sp.speaker: 3 gent.
sp.l: How the Duke graces him? what is he brother?

sp.speaker: 4 Gen.
sp.l: Do you not yet know him? A vainglorious coxcomb,
As proud as he that fell for't:
Set but aside his valour, no virtue,
Which is indeed, not fit for any courtier;
And we his fellows are as good as he,
Perhaps as capable of favour too,
For one thing or another, if 'twere looked into:
Give me a man, were I a sovereign now,
Has a good stroke at tennis, and a stiff one,
Can play at Equinoctium with the line,
As even as the thirteenth of September,
When day and night lie in a scale together:
Or may I thrive as I deserve at billiards;
No otherwise at chess, or at primero:
These are the parts required, why not advanced?

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Trust me, it was no less than excellent pleasure,
And I'm right glad 'twas thine. How fares our kinsman?
Who can resolve us best?

sp.speaker: 1 gent.
sp.l: I can my lord.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: There if I had a pity without bounds,
It might be all bestowed — a man so lost
In the wild ways of passion, that he's sensible
Of naught but what torments him?

sp.speaker: 1 gent.
sp.l: True my lord,
He runs through all the passions of mankind,
And shifts 'em strangely too: one while in love,
And that so violent, that for want of business,
He'll court the very prentice of a laundress,
Though she have kibed heels: and in's melancholy again,
He will not brook an empress, though thrice fairer
Than ever Maud was; or higher spirited
Than Cleopatra, or your English countess:
Then on a sudden he's so merry again,
Outlaughs a waiting woman, before her first child:
And turning of a hand, so angry —
'Has almost beat the Northern fellow blind;
That is for that use only; if that mood hold my lord,
' had need of a fresh man; I'll undertake,
He shall bruise three a month.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: I pity him dear:
And let it be your charge, with his kind brother,
To see his moods observed; let every passion
Be fed e'en to a surfeit, which in time
May breed a loathing: let him have enough
Of every object, that his sense is rapt with;
And being once glutted, than the taste of folly
Will come into his relish. Exit.

sp.speaker: 1 gent.
sp.l: I shall see
Your charge my lord most faithfully effected:
And how does noble Shamount?

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: Never ill man
Until I hear of baseness, than I sicken,
I am the healthful'st man i'th' kingdom else.

sp.speaker: 1 gent.
sp.l: Be armed then for a fit,Enter Lapet.
Here comes a fellow
Will make you sick at heart, if baseness do't.

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: Let me be gone: what is he?

sp.speaker: 1 gent.
sp.l: Let me tell you first,
It can be but a qualm, pray stay it out sir,
Come, you've born more than this.

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: Born? never any thing
That was injurious.

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.l: Ha, I am far from that.

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: He looks as like a man as I have seen one:
What would you speak of him? speak well I prithee,
Even for humanity's cause.

sp.speaker: 1 gent.
sp.l: You'd have it truth though?

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: What else sir? I have no reason to wrong heaven
To favour nature; let her bear her own shame
If she be faulty.

sp.speaker: 1 gent.
sp.l: Monstrous faulty there sir.

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: I'm ill at ease already.

sp.speaker: 1 gent.
sp.l: Pray bear up sir.

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: I prithee let me take him down with speed then.
Like a wild object that I would not look upon.

sp.speaker: 1 gent.
sp.l: Then thus: he's one that will endure as much
As can be laid upon him.

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: That may be noble:
I'm kept too long from his acquaintance.

sp.speaker: 1 gent.
sp.l: O sir,
Take heed of rash repentance, you're too forward
To find out virtue where it never settled:
Take the particulars first of what he endures;
Videlicet, bastinadoes by the great.

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: How!

sp.speaker: 1 gent.
sp.l: Thumps by the dozen, and your kicks by whole sale.

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: No more of him.

sp.speaker: 1 gent.
sp.l: The twinges by the nostril he snuffs up,
And holds it the best remedy for sneezing.

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: Away.

sp.speaker: 1 gent.
sp.l: Has been thrice switz't from seven o'clock till nine,
Yet with a carthorse stomach fell to breakfast,
Forgetful of his smart.

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: Nay, the disgrace on't;
There is no smart but that: base things are felt
More by their shames then hurts sir, I know you not,
But that you live an injury to nature:
I'm heartily angry with you.

sp.speaker: Lap.
sp.l: Pray give your blow or kick, and begone then:
For I never saw you before, and indeed,
Have nothing to say to you, for I know you not.

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: Why wouldst thou take a blow?

sp.speaker: Lap.
sp.l: I would not sir,
Unless 'twere offered me; and if from an enemy —
I'd be loath to deny it from a stranger.

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: What, a blow?
Endure a blow? and shall he live that gives it?

sp.speaker: Lap.
sp.l: Many a fair year — why not sir?

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: Let me wonder!
As full a man to see too, and as perfect —
I prithee live not long —

sp.speaker: Lap.
sp.l: How?

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: Let me entreat it:
Thou dost not know what wrong thou dost mankind,
To walk so long here; not to die betimes.
Let me advise thee, while thou hast to live here,
E'en for man's honour's sake, take not a blow more.

sp.speaker: Lap.
sp.l: You should advise them not to strike me then sir,
For I'll take none I assure you, less than are given.

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: How fain would I preserve man's form from shame,
And cannot get it done? however sir,
I charge thee live not long.

sp.speaker: Lap.
sp.l: This is worse than beating.

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: Of what profession art thou, tell me sir,
Besides a tailor? for I'll know the truth.

sp.speaker: Lap.
sp.l: A tailor? I'm as a good a gentleman —
Can show my arms and all.

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: How black and blue they are?
Is that your manifestation? upon pain
Of pounding thee to dust, assume not wrong fully,
The name of gentleman, because I am one,
That must not let thee live.

sp.speaker: Lap.
sp.l: I have done, I have done sir,
If there be any harm, beshrew the herald,
I am sure I ha' not been so long a gentleman,
To make this anger: I have nothing nowhere ,
But what I dear pay for. Exit.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: Groom begone;
I never was so heartsick yet of man.
Enter lady, the Duke's sister, Lapet's wife.

sp.speaker: 1. Gen.
sp.l: Here comes a cordial sir from tother sex,
Able to make a dying face look cheerful.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: The blessedness of ladies —

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: You're well met sir.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: The sight of you has put an evil from me,
Whose breath was able to make virtue sicken.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: I'm glad I came so fortunately. What was't fit?

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: A thing that takes a blow, lives and eats after it,
In very good health; you ha' not seen the like madam,
A monster worth your sixpence, lovely worth,
Speak low sir; by all likelihoods 'tis her husband,
That now bestowed a visitation on me. Farewell sir. Ex.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: Husband? is't possible that he has a wife?
Would any creature have him? 'twas some forced match,
If he were not kicked toth' church oth' wedding day,
I'll never come at court. Can be no otherwise:
Perhaps he was rich, speak mistress Lapet, was it not so?

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: Nay, that's without all question.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: O ho, he would not want kickers enough then;
If you are wise, I much suspect your honesty;
For wisdom never fastens constantly,
But upon merit: if you incline to fool,
You are alike unfit for his society;
Nay if it were not boldness in the man
That honours you, to advise you, troth his company
Should not be frequent with you.

sp.speaker: Vvise.
sp.l: 'Tis good counsel sir.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: O I am so careful where I reverence,
So just to goodness, and her precious purity,
I am as equally jealous, and as fearful,
That any undeserved stain might fall
Upon her sanctified whiteness, as of the sin
That comes by wilfulness.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: Sir, I love your thoughts,
And honour you for your counsel and your care.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: We are your servants.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: He's but a gentleman oth' chamber, he might have kissed me:
Faith, where shall one find less courtesy, then at court?
Say I have an undeserver to my husband:
That's never the worse for him: well strange lipped men,
'Tis but a kiss lost, there'll more come again. Exit.
sp.stage: Enter the passionate lord, the Duke's kinsman, makes a congee or two to nothing.

sp.speaker: 1. Gen.
sp.l: Look who comes here sir, his love fit's upon him;
I know it, by that set smile, and those congees.
How courteous he's to nothing? which indeed,
Is the next kin to woman; only shadow
The elder sister of the twain, because 'tis seen too.
See how it kisses the forefinger still;
Which is the last edition, and being come
So near the thumb every cobbler has got it?

sp.speaker: Sham.
sp.l: What a ridiculous piece, humanity
Here makes itself?

sp.speaker: 1 gent.
sp.l: Nay, good give leave a little sir,
You're so precise a manhood —

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: It afflicts me
When I behold unseemliness in an image
So near the godhead, 'tis an injury
To glorious eternity.

sp.speaker: 1 gent.
sp.l: Pray use patience sir.

sp.speaker: Passionate
sp.l: I do confess it freely precious lady,
And loves suit is so, the longer it hangs
The worse it is; better cut off sweet madam;
Oh that same drawing in your nether lip there,
Foreshows no goodness lady: make you question on't?
Shame on me but I love you.

sp.speaker: 1 gent.
sp.l: Who is't sir,
You are at all this pains for? may I know her?

sp.speaker: Passionate
sp.l: For thee thou fairest, yet the falsest woman,
That ever broke man's heartstrings.

sp.speaker: 1 gent.
sp.l: How? how's this sir?

sp.speaker: Passionate
sp.l: What, the old trick of ladies? man's apparel,
Wil't ne'er be left amongst you? steal from court in't?

sp.speaker: 1 gent.
sp.l: I see the fit grows stronger.

sp.speaker: Passionate
sp.l: Pray let's talk a little.

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: I can endure no more.

sp.speaker: 1 Gen.
sp.l: Good, let us alone a little:
You are so exact a work: love light things somewhat sir.

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: They're all but shames.

sp.speaker: 1 Gen.
sp.l: What is't you'd say to me sir?

sp.speaker: Passionate
sp.l: Can you be so forgetful to inquire it lady?

sp.speaker: 1 gent.
sp.l: Yes truly sir.

sp.speaker: Passionate
sp.l: The more I admire your stintiness:
What cause have I given you, illustrious madam,
To play this strange part with me?

sp.speaker: 1 gent.
sp.l: Cause enough,
Do but look back sir into your memory,
Your love to other women o lewd man,
'Thas almost killed my heart, you see I'm changed with it,
I ha' lost the fashion of my sex with grief on't,
When I have seen you courting of a dowdy;
Compared with me, and kissing your forefinger
To one o'th' black-guards mistresses: would not this
Crack a poor lady's heart, that believed love,
And waited for the comfort? but 'twas said sir,
A lady of my hair cannot want pitying:
The countries coming up, farewell to you sir.

sp.speaker: Passionate
sp.l: Whither intend you sir?

sp.speaker: 1 gent.
sp.l: A long journey sir:
The truth is, I'm with child, and go to travel.

sp.speaker: Passionate
sp.l: With child? I never got it.

sp.speaker: 1 gent.
sp.l: I heard you were busy
At the same time sir, and was loath to trouble you.

sp.speaker: Passionate
sp.l: Why, are not you a whore then, excellent madam?

sp.speaker: 1 gent.
sp.l: O by no means, 'twas done sir in the state
Of my belief in you, and that quits me,
It lies upon your falsehood.

sp.speaker: Passionate
sp.l: Does it so?
You shall not carry her though sir, she's my contract.

sp.speaker: 2 gent.
sp.l: I prithee thou four elements ill brewed,
Torment none but thyself; away I say
Thou beast of passion, as the drunkard is
The beast of wine; dishonour to thy making,
Thou man in fragments.

sp.speaker: Passionate
sp.l: Hear me precious madam.

sp.speaker: Sham.
sp.l: Kneel for thy wits to heaven.

sp.speaker: Passionate
sp.l: Lady, I'll father it,
Who ere begotten it: 'tis the course of greatness.

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: How virtue groans at this?

sp.speaker: Passionate
sp.l: I'll raise the court, but I'll stay your slight.

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: How wretched is that piece? Ex. Pas. lord.

sp.speaker: 1 Gen.
sp.l: He's the Duke's kinsman sir.

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: That cannot take a passion away sir,
Nor cut a fit, but one poor hour shorter,
He must endure as much as the poorest beggar,
That cannot change his money; there's the equality
In our impartial essence:
What's the news now? Ent. a servant.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: Your worthy brother sir, has left his charge,
And come to see you. Ent. Shamount's brother a soldier.

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: O the noblest welcome
That ever came from man, meet thy deservings:
Methinks I've all joys treasure in mine arms now,

sp.speaker: Soldier
sp.l: You are so fortunate in prevention brother,
You always leave the answerer barren sir,
You comprehend in few words so much worth —

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: 'Tis all too little for thee: come thou'rt welcome,
So I include all: take especial knowledge pray,
Of this dear gentleman, my absolute friend,
That loves a soldier far above a mistress,
Thou excellently faithful to 'em both.
But love to manhood, owns the purer troth. Exeunt.

div.head: Scaena prima.
div.stage: Enter Shamont's brother a soldier, and a lady the Duke's sister.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: There should be in this gallery — on they're here,
Pray sit down; believe me sir I'm weary.

sp.speaker: Soldier
sp.l: It well becomes a lady to complain a little
Of what she never feels: your walk was short madam,
You can be but afraid of weariness;
Which well employs the softness of your sex,
As for the thing itself, you never came to't.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: You're wondrously well read in lady's sir.

sp.speaker: Soldier
sp.l: Shall I think such a creature as you madam,
Was ever born to feel pain, but in travel?
There's your full portion,
Besides a little toothache in the breeding,
Which a kind husband too, takes from you madam.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: But where do ladies sir, find such kind husbands?
Perhaps you have heard
The rheumatic story of some loving chandler now,
Or some such melting fellow, that you talk
So prodigal of men's kindness: I confess sir,
Many of those wives are happy, their ambition
Does reach no higher, than to love and ignorance,
Which makes an excellent husband, and a fond one:
Now sir, your great ones aim at height, and cunning,
And so are oft deceived, yet they must venture it;
For 'tis a lady's contumely sir,
To have a lord an ignorant; then the world's voice
Will deem her for a wanton ere she taste on't:
But to deceive a wise man, to whose circumspection,
The world resigns itself with all his envy;
'Tis less dishonour to us then to fall,
Because his believed wisdom keeps out all.

sp.speaker: Soldier
sp.l: Would I were the man lady, that should venture
His wisdom to your goodness.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: You might fail
In the return, as many men have done sir:
I dare not justify what is to come of me,
Because I know it not, though I hope virtuously;
Marry what's past or present, I durst put
Into a good man's hand, which if he take
Upon my word for good, it shall not cozen him.

sp.speaker: Soldier
sp.l: No, nor her after?

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: It may hap so too sir:
A woman's goodness, when she is a wise,
Lies much upon a man's desert, believe it sir,
If there be fault in her, I'll pawn my life on't,
'Tis first in him, if she were ever good,
That makes one; knowing not a husband yet,
Or what he may be, I promise no more virtues,
Than I may well perform, for that were cozenage.

sp.speaker: Soldier
sp.l: Happy were he that had you with all fears,
That's my opinion, lady.

div.stage: Enter Shamont and a servant listening.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: What say you now sir?
Dare you give confidence to your own eyes?

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: Not yet I dare not.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: No?

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: Scarce yet, or yet:
Although I see 'tis he. Why can a thing,
That's but myself divided be so false?

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: Nay do but mark how the chair plays his part too:
How amorously 'tis bent.

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: Hell take thy bad thoughts,
For they are strange ones. Never take delight
To make a torment worse. Look on 'em heaven,
For that's a brother: send me a fair enemy,
And take him; for a fouler fiend there breathes not:
I will not sin, to think there's ill in her,
But what's of his producing.
Yet goodness, whose enclosure is but flesh,
Holds out oft times but sorrily. But as black sir,
As ever kindred was: I hate mine own blood,
Because it is so near thine. Live without honesty,
And mayst thou die with an unmoistened eye,
And no tear follow thee. Ex. Shamont, servant.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: You're wondrous merry sir; I would your brother heard you.

sp.speaker: Soldier
sp.l: O my sister
I would not out oth' way, let fall my words lady,
Por the precisest humour.

sp.speaker: Passionate
sp.l: Yea, so close.

sp.speaker: Soldier
sp.l: They're merry, that's the worst you can report on 'em;
They're neither dangerous, nor immodest.

sp.speaker: Passionate
sp.l: So sir,
Shall I believe you, think you?

sp.speaker: Soldier
sp.l: Who's this lady?

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: O the Duke's cousin; he came late from travel sir.

sp.speaker: Soldier
sp.l: Respect belongs to him.

sp.speaker: Passionate
sp.l: For as I said lady,
They're merry that's the worst you can report of 'em:
They're neither dangerous, nor immodest.

sp.speaker: Soldier
sp.l: How's this?

sp.speaker: Passionate
sp.l: And there I think I left.

sp.speaker: Soldier
sp.l: Abuses me.

sp.speaker: Passionate
sp.l: Now to proceed, lady; perhaps I swore I loved you,
If you believe me not, you're much the wiser.

sp.speaker: Soldier
sp.l: He speaks still in my person, and derides me.

sp.speaker: Passionate
sp.l: For I can cog with you.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: You can all do so.
We make no question of men's promptness that way.

sp.speaker: Passionate
sp.l: And smile, and wave a chair with comely grace too,
Play with our tastle gently, and do fine things,
That catch a lady sooner than a virtue.

sp.speaker: Soldier
sp.l: I never used to let man live so long
That wronged me.

sp.speaker: Passionate
sp.l: Talk of battalions, woo you in a skirmish;
Divine my mind to you lady; and being sharp set,
Can court you at half pike: or name your weapon,
We cannot fail you lady. Enter 1 Gen.

sp.speaker: Soldier
sp.l: Now he dies:
Were all succeeding hopes stored up within him.

sp.speaker: 1 Ge.
sp.l: O fie, i'th' court sir?

sp.speaker: Soldier
sp.l: I most dear thank you sir.

sp.speaker: 1 Ge.
sp.l: 'Tis rage ill spent upon a passionate madman.

sp.speaker: Soldier
sp.l: That shall not privilege him for ever sir:
A madman call you him? I have found too much reason
Sound in his injury to me, to believe him so.

sp.speaker: 1 Ge.
sp.l: If ever truth from man's lips may be held
In reputation with you, give this confidence;
And this his love-fit, which we observe still,
By's flattering and his fineness: at some other time,
He'll go as slovenly as heart can wish.
The love and pity that his highness shows to him,
Makes every man the more respectful of him:
Has never a passion, but is well provided for,
As this of love, he is full fed in all;
His swinge as I may term it: have but patience,
And ye shall witness somewhat.

sp.speaker: Soldier
sp.l: Still he mocks me:
Look you, in action, in behaviour sir;
Hold still the chair, with a grand mischief to you,
Or I'll set so much strength upon your heart sir —

sp.speaker: Passionate
sp.l: I feel some power has restrained me lady:
If it be sent from love, say, I obey it,
And ever keep a voice to welcome it.
Thou deity, swift winged love,
Sometimes below, sometimes above,
Little in shape, but great in power,
Thou that makest a heart thy tower,
And thy loopholes, lady's eyes,
From whence thou strikest the fond and wise.
Did all the shafts in thy fair quiver
Stick fast in my ambitious liver;
Yet thy power would I adore,
And call upon thee to shoot more.
Shoot more, shoot more.

div.stage: Enter one like a Cupid offering to shoot at him.

sp.speaker: Passionate
sp.l: I prithee hold though, sweet celestial boy;
I'm not requited yet with love enough,
For the first arrow that I have within me:
And if thou be an equal archer Cupid,
Shoot this lady, and twenty more for me.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: Me sir?

sp.speaker: 1 Gen.
sp.l: 'Tis nothing but device, fear it not lady;
You may be as good a maid after that shaft madam,
As ere your mother was at twelve and half:
'Tis like the boy that draws it, 'thas no sting yet.

sp.speaker: Cup.
sp.l: 'Tis like the miserable maid that draws it — aside.
That sees no comfort yet, seeing him so passionate.

sp.speaker: Passionate
sp.l: Strike me the Duchess of Valois in love with me,
With all the speed thou canst, and two of her women.

sp.speaker: Cu.
sp.l: You shall have more. Exit.

sp.speaker: Passionate
sp.l: Tell 'em I tarry for 'em.

sp.speaker: 1 Gen.
sp.l: Who would be angry with that walking trouble now
That hurts none but itself?

sp.speaker: Soldier
sp.l: I am better quieted.

sp.speaker: Passionate
sp.l: I'll have all womenkind struck in time for me
After thirteen once:
I see this Cupid will not let me want,
And let him spend his forty shafts an hour,
They shall be all found from the Duke's exchequer;
He's come already.

div.stage: Enter again the same Cupid, two brothers, 6 women maskers, Cupid's bow bent all the way towards them, the first woman singing and playing, a priest.

sp.l: O turn thy bow,
Thy power we feel and know,
Fair Cupid turn away thy bow:
They be those golden arrows,
Bring ladies all their sorrows,
And till there be more truth in men,
Never shoot at maid again.

sp.speaker: Passionate
sp.l: What a felicity of whores are here?
And all my concubines, struck bleeding new:
A man can in his life time make but one woman,
But he may make his fifty queans a month.

sp.speaker: Cu.
sp.l: Have you remembered a priest honest brothers?

sp.speaker: 1 Bro.
sp.l: Yes sister, and this is the young gentleman,
Make you no question of our faithfulness.

sp.speaker: 2 Bro.
sp.l: His growing shame sister provokes our care.

sp.speaker: Priest.
sp.l: He must be taken in this fit of love gentlemen.

sp.speaker: 1 Bro.
sp.l: What else sir? he shall do't.

sp.speaker: 2 Bro.
sp.l: Enough.

sp.speaker: 1 Bro.
sp.l: Be cheerful wench. A dance, Cupid leading.

sp.speaker: Passionate
sp.l: Now by the stroke of pleasure, a deep oath,
Nimbly hopped ladies all; what height they bear too?
A story higher than your common statures;
A little man must go up stairs to kiss 'em:
What a great space there is
Betwixt love's dining chamber, and his garret?
I'll try the utmost height — the garret stoops methinks;
The rooms are made all bending, I see that,
And not so high as a man takes 'em for.

sp.speaker: Cu.
sp.l: Now if you'll follow me sir, I've that power,
To make them follow you.

sp.speaker: Passionate
sp.l: Are they all shot?

sp.speaker: Cu.
sp.l: All, all sir, every mother's daughter of 'em.

sp.speaker: Passionate
sp.l: Then there's no fear of following; if they be once shot,
They'll follow a man to th' devil — as for you sir —Ex. with the lady, and the maskers.

sp.speaker: Soldier
sp.l: Me sir?

sp.speaker: 1 gent.
sp.l: Nay sweet sir.

sp.speaker: Soldier
sp.l: A noise, a threatening; did you not hear it sir?

sp.speaker: 1 gent.
sp.l: Without regard sir, so would I hear you.

sp.speaker: Soldier
sp.l: This must come to something, never talk of that sir,
You never saw it otherwise.

sp.speaker: 1 Gen.
sp.l: Nay dear merit —

sp.speaker: Soldier
sp.l: Me above all men?

sp.speaker: 1 Gen.
sp.l: Troth you wrong your anger.

sp.speaker: Soldier
sp.l: I will be armed my honourable lecher.

sp.speaker: 1 gent.
sp.l: O fie sweet sir.

sp.speaker: Soldier
sp.l: That devours women's honesties by lumps,
And never chawst thy pleasure.

sp.speaker: 1 gent.
sp.l: What do you mean sir?

sp.speaker: Soldier
sp.l: What does he mean t'engross all to himself?
There's others love a whore, as well as he sir.

sp.speaker: 1 Gen.
sp.l: O an' that be part o'th fury, we have a city
Is very well provided for that case;
Let him alone with her, sir we have women
Are very charitable to proper men,
And to a soldier that has all his limbs;
Marry the sick and lame gets not a penny:
Right women's charity, and the husbands follow't too:
Here comes his highness sir.

sp.speaker: Soldier
sp.l: I'll walk to cool myself. Exit.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Who's that?

sp.speaker: 1 Gen.
sp.l: The brother of Shamont.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: He's brother then
To all the courts love, they that love discreetly,
And place their friendliness upon desert:
As for the rest, that with a double face
Look upon merit, much like fortune's visage,
That looks two ways, both to lives calms and storms,
I'll so provide for him, chiefly for him,
He shall not wish their loves, nor dread their envies.
And here comes my Shamont. Enter Shamont.

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: That ladies virtues are my only joys,
And he to offer to lay siege to them?

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Shamont.

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: Her goodness is my pride; in all discourses,
As often as I hear rash tongued gallants,
Speak rudely of a woman, presently
I give in but her name, and they're all silent:
Oh who would lose this benefit?

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Come hither sir.

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: 'Tis like the gift of healing, but diviner;
For that but cures diseases in the body,
This works a cure on fame, on reputation:
The noblest piece of surgery upon earth.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Shamont; he minds me not.

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: A brother do't?

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.p: Shamont I say. Gives him a touch with his switch.

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: Ha?
If he be mortal, by this hand he perishes;Draws.
Unless it be a stroke from heaven, he dies for't.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Why, how now sir? 'twas I.

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: The more's my misery.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Why, what's the matter prithee?

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: Can you ask it sir?
No man else should; stood forty lives before him
By this I would have opened my way to him;
It could not be you sir, excuse him not,
Whate'er he be, as you're dear to honour,
That I may find my peace again.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Forbear I say.
Upon my love to truth, 'twas none but I.

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: Still miserable?

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Come, come, what ails you sir?

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: Never sat shame cooling so long upon me,
Without a satisfaction in revenge,
And heaven has made it here a sin to wish it.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Hark you sir?

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: O you've undone me.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: How?

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: Cruelly undone me;
I have lost my peace, and reputation by you:
Sir pardon me, I can never love you more. Exit.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: What language call you this sirs?

sp.speaker: 1 Gen.
sp.l: Truth my lord, I've seldom heard a stranger. —

sp.speaker: 2 gent,
sp.l: He is a man of a most curious valour,
Wondrous precise, and punctual in that virtue.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: But why to me so punctual? my last thought
Was most entirely fixed on his advancement:
Why, I came now to put him in possession
Of his fair fortunes: what a misconceiver 'tis?
And from a gentleman of our chamber merely,
Made him vice-admiral; I was settled in't,
I love him next to health: call him gentlemen;
Why would not you, or you ha' taken as much,
And never murmured? Exit. 1 gent.

sp.speaker: 2 gent.
sp.l: Troth, I think we should my lord,
And there's a fellow walks about the court,
Would take a hundred of 'em.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: I hate you all for't,
And rather praise his high pitched fortitude,
Though in extremes for niceness: now I think on't,
I would I had never done't. — now sir, where is he?

sp.speaker: 1 gent.
sp.l: His suit is only sit to be excused.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: He shall not be excused, I love him dearelier:
Say we entreat him; go, he must not leave us. Ex. 2 Gen.
So virtue bless me, I ne'er knew him paralleled;
Why, he's more precious to me now, then ever.

sp.speaker: 2 gent.
sp.l: With much fair language, we've brought him?

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Thanks — where is he?

sp.speaker: 2 gent.
sp.l: Yonder sir.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Come forward man.

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: Pray pardon me, I'm ashamed to be seen sir.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Was ever such a touchy man heard of?
Prithee come nearer.

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: More into the light?
Put not such cruelty into your requests my lord,
First to disgrace me publicly, and then draw me
Into men's eyesight, with the shame yet hot
Upon my reputation.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: What disgrace sir?

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: What?
Such as there can be no forgiveness for,
That I can find in honour.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: That's most strange sir.

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: Yet I have searched my bosom to find one,
And wrestled with my inclination,
But 't will not be: would you had killed me sir,
With what an ease had I forgiven you then?
But to endure a stroke from any hand
Under a punishing angels, which is justice,
Honour disclaim that man, for my part chiefly:
Had it been yet the malice of your sword.
Though it had cleft me, 'thad been noble to me;
You should have found my thanks paid in a smile
If I had fell unworded; but to shame me,
With the correction that your horse should have,
Were you ten thousand times my royal lord,
I cannot love you never, nor desire to serve you more.
If your drum call me. I am vowed to valour,
But peace shall never know me yours again,
Because I've lost mine own, I speak to die sir;
Would you were gracious that way to take off shame,
With the same swiftness as you pour it on:
And since it is not in the power of monarchs
To make a gentleman, which is a substance
Only begotten of merit, they should be careful
Not to destroy the worth of one so rare,
Which neither they can make; nor lost, repair. Exit.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: You've set a fair light sir before my judgement,
Which burns with wondrous clearness; I acknowledge it,
And your worth with it: but then sir, my love,
My love — what gone again?

sp.speaker: 1 Gen.
sp.l: And full of scorn my lord.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: That language will undo the man that keeps it,
Who knows no difference twixt contempt and manhood.
Upon your love to goodness, gentlemen,Enter a huntsman
Let me not lose him long: how now?

sp.speaker: Huntsman
sp.l: The game's at height my lord.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Confound both, thee and it: hence break it off;
He hates me brings me news of any pleasure:
I felt not such a conflict since I could;
Distinguish betwixt worthiness and bloodEx.

div.head: Scaena prima.
div.stage: Enter the two brothers, 1 gentleman, with those that were the maskers, and the Cupid.

sp.speaker: 1 Gen.
sp.l: I I heartily commend your project gentlemen,
'Twas wise and virtuous.

sp.speaker: 1 Bro.
sp.l: 'Twas for the safety
Of precious honour sir, which near blood binds us to:
He promised the poor easy fool there marriage,
There was a good maidenhead lost i'th' belief on't,
Beshrew her hasty confidence.

sp.speaker: 1 Gen.
sp.l: O no more sir,
You make her weep again; alas poor Cupid:
Shall she not shift herself?

sp.speaker: 1 Bro.
sp.l: O by no means sir:
We dare not have her seen yet, all the while
She keeps this shape, 'tis but thought device,
And she may follow him so without suspicion,
To see if she can draw all his wild passions,
To one point only, and that's love, the main point:
So far his highness grants, and gave at first,
Large approbation to the quick conceit,
Which then was quick indeed.

sp.speaker: 1 gent.
sp.l: You make her blush insooth.

sp.speaker: 1 Bro.
sp.l: I fear 'tis more the flag of shame, than grace sir.

sp.speaker: 1 Gen.
sp.l: They both give but one kind of colour sir:
If it be bashfulness in that kind taken,
It is the same with grace; and there she weeps again.
In truth you're too hard, much, much too bitter sir,
Unless you mean to have her weep her eyes out,
To play a Cupid truly.

sp.speaker: 1 Bro.
sp.l: Come, ha' done then:
We should all fear to sin first; for 'tis certain,
When 'tis once lodged, though entertained in mirth,
It must be wept out, if it ere come forth.

sp.speaker: 1 gent.
sp.l: Now 'tis so well, I'll leave you.

sp.speaker: 1 Bro.
sp.l: Faithfully welcome sir,
Go Cupid to your charge; he's your own now;
If he want love, none will be blamed but you.

sp.speaker: Cu.
sp.l: The strangest marriage, and unfortunatest bride
That ever humane memory contained;
I cannot be myself for't. Exit.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.l: O gentlemen? Enter the clown.

sp.speaker: 1 Bro.
sp.l: How now sir, what's the matter?

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.l: His melancholy passion is half spent already,
Then comes his angry fit at the very tail on't,
Then comes in my pain gentlemen; 'Has beaten me e'en to a cullis.
I am nothing, right worshipful, but very pap,
And jelly: I have no bones, my body's all one business,
They talk of ribs, and chines most freely abroad i'th' world,
Why, I have no such thing; whoever lives to see me dead
Gentlemen, shall find me all mummy good to fill galipots
And long dildo glasses: I shall not have a bone to throw
At a dog.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.l: Alas poor vassal, how he goes?

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.l: O gentlemen,
I am unjointed, do but think of that:
My breast is beat into my maw, that what I eat,
I am fain to take't in all at mouth with spoons;
A lamentable hearing; and 'tis well known, my belly
Is driven into my back.
I earned four crowns a month, most dear gentlemen,
And one he must have when the fit's upon him,
The privy purse allows it, and 'tis thriftiness,
He would break else some forty pounds in casements,
And in five hundred years undo the kingdom:
I have cast it up to a quarrel.

sp.speaker: 1 Bro.
sp.l: There's a fellow kicked about court, I would
He had his place brother, but for one fit of his indignation.

sp.speaker: 2 Bro.
sp.l: And suddenly I have thought upon a means for't.

sp.speaker: 1 Bro.
sp.l: I prithee how?

sp.speaker: 2 Bro.
sp.l: 'Tis but preferring brother
This stockfish to his service, with a letter
Of commendations, the same way he wishes it,
And than you win his heart: for of my knowledge
He has laid wait this half year for a fellow
That will be beaten; and with a safe conscience
We may commend the carriage of this man in't;
Now servants he has kept, lusty tall feeders,
But they have beaten him, and turned themselves away:
Now one that would endure, is like to stay,
And get good wages of him; and the service too
Is ten times milder brother, I would not wish it else.
I see the fellow has a sore crushed body,
And the more need he has to be kicked at ease.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: I sweet gentlemen, a kick of ease, send me to such a master.

sp.speaker: 2 Bro.
sp.l: No more I say, we have one for thee, a soft footed master,
One that wears wool in's toes.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: O gentlemen, soft garments may you wear,
Soft skins may you wed,
But as plump as pillows, both for white and red.
And now will I reveal a secret to you,
Since you provide for my poor flesh so tenderly,
'Has hired mere rogues, out of his chamber window,
To beat the soldier, monsieur Shamonts brother.

sp.speaker: 1 Bro.
sp.l: That nothing concerns us sir.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.l: For no cause gentlemen,
Unless it be for wearing shoulder points,
With longer tags than his.

sp.speaker: 2 Bro.
sp.l: Is not that somewhat?
Billakin sir, the difference of long tags,
Has cost many a man's life, and advanced other some,
Come follow me.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.l: See what a gull am I:
O every man in his profession;
I know a thump now, as judiciously,
As the proudest he that walks, I'll except none;
Come to a tag, how short I fall? I'm gone.Exeunt

sp.speaker: Lap.
sp.l: I have been ruminating with myself,
What honour a man loses by a kick:
Why, what's a kick? the fury of a foot,
Whose indignation commonly is stamped
Upon the hinder quarter of a man;
Which is a place very unfit for honour,
The world will confess so much:
Then what disgrace I pray, does that part suffer
Where honour never comes, I'd fain know that?
This being well forced, and urged, may have the power
To move most gallants to take kicks in time,
And spurn out the duelloes out o'th' kingdom,
For they that stand upon their honour most,
When they conceive there is no honour lost,
As by a table that I have invented
For that purpose alone, shall appear plainly,
Which shows the vanity of all blows at large,
And with what ease they may be taken of all sides,
Numbering but twice one the letter's patience
From C.p. to E. I doubt not but in small time
To see a dissolution of all bloodshed,
If the reformed kick do but once get up:
For what a lamentable folly 'tis,
If we observ't, for every little justle,
Which is but the ninth part of a sound thump,
In our meek computation, we must fight forsooth, yes,
If kill, I'm hang '; if I be killed myself,
I die for't also: is not this trim wisdom?
Now for the con, a man may be well beaten,
Yet pass away his fourscore years smooth after:
I had a father did it, and to my power
I will not be behind him. Enter Shamont.

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: O well met.

sp.speaker: Lap.
sp.l: Now a fine punch or two, I look for't duly.

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: I've been to seek you.

sp.speaker: Lap.
sp.l: Let me know your lodging sir,
I'll come to you once a day, and use your pleasure sir.

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: I'm made the fittest man for thy society:
I'll live and die with thee: come show me a chamber;
There is no house but thine, but only thine,
That's fit to cover me: I've taken a blow sirrah.

sp.speaker: Lap.
sp.l: I would you had indeed: why, you may see sir;
You'll all come to't in time, when my book's out.

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: Since I did see thee last, I've taken a blow.

sp.speaker: Lap.
sp.p: Pha sir that's nothing; I ha' taken forty since.

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: What? and I charged thee thou shouldst not?

sp.speaker: Lap.
sp.l: Ay sir, you might charge your pleasure,
But they would give't me, whether I would or no.

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: O I walk without my peace, I've no companion now;
Prithee resolve me, for I cannot ask
A man more beaten to experience,
Than thou art in this kind, what manner of blow
Is held the most disgraceful, or distasteful?
For thou dost only censure 'em by the hurt,
Not by the shame they do thee: yet having felt
Abuses of all kinds, thou mayst deliver,
Though't be by chance, the most injurious one.

sp.speaker: Lap.
sp.l: You put me to't sir; but to tell you truth,
They're all as one with me, little exception.

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: That little may do much, let's have it from you.

sp.speaker: Lap.
sp.l: With all the speed I may: first then, and foremost,
I hold so reverently of the bastinado sir,
That if it were the dearest friend i'th' world,
I'd put it into his hand.

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: Go too, I'll pass that then.

sp.speaker: Lap.
sp.l: You're the more happy sir,
Would I were passed it too:
But being accustomed to't, it is the better carried.

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: Will you forward?

sp.speaker: Lap.
sp.l: Then there's your souse, your wherret, and your doused,
Tugs on the hair, your bob o'th' lips, a whelp on't,
I ne'er could find much difference: now your thump,
A thing derived first from your hemp-beaters,
Takes a man's wind away, most spitefully:
There's nothing that destroys a colic like it,
For't leaves no wind i'th' body.

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: On sir, on.

sp.speaker: Lap.
sp.l: Pray give me leave, I'm out of breath with thinking on't.

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: This is far off yet.

sp.speaker: Lap.
sp.l: For the twinge byth' nose,
'Tis certainly unsightly, so my tables says,
But helps against the headache, wondrous strangely.

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: Is't possible?

sp.speaker: Lap.
sp.l: O your crushed nostrils slakes your oppilation
And makes your pent powers flush to wholesome sneezes.

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: I never thought there had been half that virtue
In a wrung nose before.

sp.speaker: Lap.
sp.l: O plenitude sir:
Now come we lower, to our modern kick,
Which has been mightily in use of late,
Since our young men drank coltsfoot: and I grant you,
'Tis a most scornful wrong, cause the foot plays it;
But mark again, how we that take't, requite it
With the like scorn, for we receive it backward;
And can there be a worse disgrace retorted?

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: And is this all?

sp.speaker: Lap.
sp.l: All but a lug byth' ear,
Or such a trifle.

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: Happy sufferer,
All this is nothing to the wrong I bear:
I see the worst disgrace, thou never feltst yet;
It is so far from thee, thou canst not think on't;
Nor dare I let thee know, it is so abject.

sp.speaker: Lap.
sp.l: I would you would though, that I might prepare for't,
For I shall have't at one time or another:
If't be a thwack, I make account of that;
There's no new fashioned swap that ere came up yet,
But I've the first on 'em, I thank 'em for't.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: Hast thou enquired?

sp.speaker: 1 servant
sp.l: But can hear nothing madam.

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: If there be but so much substance in thee
To make a shelter for a man disgraced,
Hide my departure from that glorious woman
That comes with all perfection about her:
So noble, that I dare not be seen of her,
Since shame took hold of me: upon thy life
No mention of me.

sp.speaker: Lap.
sp.l: I'll cut out my tongue first,
Before I'll lose my life, there's more belongs to't.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: See there's a gentleman, inquire of him.

sp.speaker: 2 servant
sp.l: For monsieur Shamont madam?

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: For whom else sir?

sp.speaker: 1 servant
sp.l: Why, this fellow dares not see him.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: How?

sp.speaker: 1 servant
sp.l: Shamont madam?
His very name's worse than a favour to him,
And when he cries, there's nothing stills him sooner;
Madam, your page of thirteen is too hard for him,
'Twas tried i'th' woodyard.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: Alas poor grieved merit!
What is become of him? if he one fail,
Virtue shall find small friendship: farewell then
To ladies' worths, for any hope in men,
He loved for goodness, not for wealth, or lust,
After the world's foul dotage, he ne'er courted
The body but the beauty of the mind,
A thing which common courtship never thinks on:
All his affections were so sweet and fair,
There is no hope for fame if he despair. Ex. Lad. and Ser.

div.stage: Enter the clown. He kicks Lapet.

sp.speaker: Lap.
sp.l: Good morrow to you again most heartily sir,
Cry you mercy I heard you not, I was somewhat busy.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.l: He takes it as familiarly, as an ave,
Or precious salutation: I was sick till I had one,
Because I am so used to't.

sp.speaker: Lap.
sp.l: However you deserve, your friends and mine, here
Give you large commendations i' this letter,
They say you will endure well.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.l: I'd be loath
To prove 'em liars: I've endured as much
As mortal pen and ink can set me down for.

sp.speaker: Lap.
sp.l: Say you me so?

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.l: I know and feel it so sir,
I have it under black and white already;
I need no pen to paint me out.

sp.speaker: Lap.
sp.l: He fits me,
And hits my wishes pat, pat: I was ne'er
In possibility to be better maned,
For he's half lamed already, I see't plain,
But take no notice on't, for fear I make
The rascal proud, and dear, to advance his wages;
First let me grow into particulars with you;
What have you endured of worth? let me hear.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.l: Marry sir, I'm almost beaten blind.

sp.speaker: Lap.
sp.l: That's pretty well for a beginning,
But many a mill-horse has endured as much.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.l: Shame of the miller's heart for his unkindness then.

sp.speaker: Lap.
sp.l: Well sir, what then?

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: I've been twice thrown down stairs, just before supper.

sp.speaker: Lap.
sp.l: Puh, so have I, that's nothing.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.l: I but sir,
Was yours pray before supper?

sp.speaker: Lap.
sp.l: There thou posest me.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.l: I marry, that's it, 't'ad been less grief to me,
Had I but filled my belly, and then tumbled,
But to be flung down fasting, there's the dolour.

sp.speaker: Lap.
sp.l: It would have grieved me, that indeed: proceed sir.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.l: I have been plucked and tugged byth'hair o'th' head
About a gallery, half an acre long.

sp.speaker: Lap.
sp.l: Yes, that's a good one, I must needs confess,
A principal good one that, an absolute good one,
I have been trod upon, and spurned about,
But never tugged byth' hair, I thank my fates.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.l: O 'tis a spiteful pain.

sp.speaker: Lap.
sp.l: Peace, never speak on't,
For putting men in mind on't.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.l: To conclude,
I'm bursten sir: my belly will hold no meat.

sp.speaker: Lap.
sp.l: No? that makes amends for all.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.l: Unless't be puddings,
Or such fast food, any loose thing beguiles me, I'm never the better for't.

sp.speaker: Lap.
sp.l: Shepherds will stay with thee?

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.l: Yes sir, or cauldrons.

sp.speaker: Lap.
sp.l: Very well sir:
Any your bursten fellows must take heed of surfeits:
Strange things it seems, you have endured;

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.l: Too true sir.

sp.speaker: Lap.
sp.l: But now the question is, what you will endure
Hereafter in my service?

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.l: Any thing
That shall be reason sir, for I'm but froth;
Much like a thing new calved, or come more nearer sir,
You've seen a cluster of frog-spawns in April,
E'en such a starch am I, as weak and tender
As a green woman yet.

sp.speaker: Lap.
sp.l: Now I know this,
I will be very gently angry with thee,
And kick thee carefully.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.l: O I sweet sir.

sp.speaker: Lap.
sp.l: Peace, when thou art offered well, lest I begin now.
Your friends and mine have writ here for your truth,
They'll pass their words themselves, and I must meet 'em.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.l: Then have you all:Exit.
As for my honesty there is no fear of that,
For I have never a whole bone about me,Exit.

div.stage: Music, enter the passionate cousin, rudely, and carelessly apparelled, unbraced, and untrust: the Cupid following.

sp.speaker: Cup.
sp.l: Think upon love, which makes all creatures handsome,
Seemly for eyesight; go not so disfusedly,
There are great ladies purpose sir to visit you.

sp.speaker: Passionate
sp.l: Grand plagues, shut in my casements, that the breathes
Of their coach-mares reek not into my nostrils;
Those beasts are but a kind of bawdy forerunners.

sp.speaker: Cup.
sp.l: It is not well with you,
When you speak ill of fair ladies.

sp.speaker: Passionate
sp.l: Fair mischiefs, give me a nest of owls, and take 'em;
Happy is he say I, whose window opens
To a brown baker's chimney, he shall be sure there
To hear the bird sometimes after twilight:
What a fine thing 'tis methinks to have our garments
Sit loose upon us thus, thus carelessly,
It is more manly, and more mortifying;
For we're so much the readier for our shrouds:
For how ridiculous were't, to have death come,
And take a fellow pinned up like a mistress?
About his neck a ruff, like a pincht lantern,
Which schoolboys make in winter; and his doublet
So close and pent, as if he feared one prison
Would not be strong enough, to keep his soul in;
But's tailor makes another:
And trust me, for I know't when I loved Cupid,
He does endure much pain, for the poor praise
Of a neat fitting suit.

sp.speaker: Cup.
sp.l: One may be handsome sir,
And yet not pained, nor proud.

sp.speaker: Passionate
sp.l: There you lie Cupid,
As bad as Mercury: there is no handsomeness,
But has a wash of pride and luxury,
And you go there too Cupid. Away dissembler,
Thou takest the deed's part which befools us all;
Thy arrow heads shoot out sinners: hence away,
And after thee I'll send a powerful charm,
Shall banish thee for ever.

sp.speaker: Cup.
sp.l: Never, never,
I am too sure thine own. Exit.

sp.speaker: Passionate
sp.l: Hence all you vain delights,
As short as are the nights,
Wherein you spend your folly,
There's naught in this life sweet,
If man were wise to see't,
But only melancholy,
Oh sweetest melancholy.
Welcome folded arms, and fixed eyes,
A sigh that piercing mortifies,
A look that's fastened to the ground,
A tongue chained up without a sound.
Fountain heads, and pathless groves,
Places which pale passion loves:
Moonlight walks, when all the fowls
Are warmly housed, save bats and owls;
A midnight bell, a parting groan,
These are the sounds we feed upon;
Then stretch our bones in a still gloomy valley,
Nothing's so dainty sweet as lovely melancholy.

div.stage: Enter at another door Lapet, the Cupids brothers watching his coming.

sp.speaker: 1 Br.
sp.l: So, so, the woodcock's ginned;
Keep this door fast brother.

sp.speaker: 2 Bro.
sp.l: I'll warrant this.

sp.speaker: 1 Bro.
sp.l: I'll go incense him instantly;
I know the way to't.

sp.speaker: 2 Bro.
sp.l: Wil't not be too soon think you,
And make two fits break into one?

sp.speaker: 1 Bro.
sp.l: Pah, no, no; the tail of his melancholy
Is always the head of his anger, and follows as close,
As the report follows the powder.

sp.speaker: Lap.
sp.l: This is the appointed place, and the hour struck,
If I can get security for's truth,
I'll never mind his honesty: poor worm,
I durst lay him by my wife, which is a benefit
Which many masters ha' not: I shall ha' no maid
Now got with child, but what I get myself,
And that's no small felicity: in most places
They're got by th' men, and put upon the masters:
Nor shall I be resisted when I strike,
For he can hardly stand; these are great blessings.

sp.speaker: Passionate
sp.l: I want my food, deliver me a varlet.Within.

sp.speaker: Lap.
sp.l: How now: from whence comes that?

sp.speaker: Passionate
sp.l: I am allowed a carcase to insult on;
Where's the villain?

sp.speaker: Lap.
sp.l: He means not me I hope.

sp.speaker: Passionate
sp.l: My maintenance rascals; my bulk, my exhibition.

sp.speaker: Lap.
sp.l: Bless us all,
What names 'Are these? would I were gone again.

div.stage: The passionate man enters in fury, with a truncheon,

sp.l: A curse upon thee for a slave,
Art thou here, and heardest me rave?
Fly not sparkles from mine eye,
To show my indignation nigh?
Am I not all foam, and fire?
With voice as hoarse, as a town-crier?
How my back opens and shuts together,
With fury, as old men's with weather?
Couldst thou not hear my teeth knash hither?

sp.speaker: Lap.
sp.l: No truly sir, I thought t'had been a squirrel,
Shaving a hazelnut.

sp.speaker: Passionate
sp.l: Death, hell, fiends, and darkness,
I will thrash thy mangy carcase.

sp.speaker: Lap.
sp.l: O sweet sir.

sp.speaker: Passionate
sp.l: There cannot be too many tortures,
Spent upon those lousy quarters.

sp.speaker: Lap.
sp.l: Hold, o. Falls down for dead.

sp.speaker: Passionate
sp.l: Thy bones shall rue, thy bones shall rue,

body.l: Thou nafly, scurvy, mongrill toad,Sings again.
Better a thousand lives it cost,
Then have brave anger spilt or lost. Exit.

sp.speaker: Lap.
sp.l: May I open mine eyes yet, and safely peep?
I'll try a groan first — o — nay then he's gone.
There was no other policy but to die,
He would ha' made me else. Ribs are you sore?
I was never beaten to a tune before.

sp.speaker: 1 Bro.
sp.l: Lapet.

sp.speaker: Lap.
sp.l: Again? Falls again.

sp.speaker: 1 Bro.
sp.l: Look, look, he's flat again,
And stretched out like a corse a handful longer
Than he walks trust me brother. Why Lapet.
I hold my life we shall not get him speak now.
Monsieur Lapet; it must be a privy token,
If any thing fetch him, he's so far gone.
We come to pass our words for your man's truth.

sp.speaker: Lap.
sp.l: O gentlemen you're welcome: I have been thrashed i'faith.

sp.speaker: 2 Bro.
sp.l: How? thrashed sir?

sp.speaker: Lap
sp.l: Never was Shrove-tuesday bird
So cudgeled gentlemen.

sp.speaker: 1 Bro.
sp.l: Pray how? by whom sir?

sp.speaker: Lap.
sp.l: Nay that I know not.

sp.speaker: 1 Bro.
sp.l: Not who did this wrong?

sp.speaker: Lap.
sp.l: Only a thing came like a walking song.

sp.speaker: 1 Bro.
sp.l: What beaten with a song?

sp.speaker: Lap.
sp.l: Never more tightly, gentlemen:
Such crotchets happen now and then, methinks,
He that endures well, of all waters drinks. Exeunt.

div.head: Scaena prima.
div.stage: Enter Shamont's brother, the soldier, and 1. Gent.

sp.speaker: Soldier
sp.l: Yes, yes, this was a madman, sir, with you,
A passionate madman.

sp.speaker: 1. Gent.
sp.l: Who would ha' looked for this sir?

sp.speaker: Soldier
sp.l: And must be privileged? A pox privilege him:
I was never so dry beaten since I was born,
And by a litter of rogues, mere rogues, the whole twenty
Had not above nine elbows amongst 'em all too:
And the most part of those left-handed rascals,
The very vomit, sir, of hospitals,
Bridewells, and spittle-houses; such nasty smellers,
That if they'd been unfurnished of club-trunchions,
They might have cudgeled me with their very stinks,
It was so strong, and sturdy: and shall this,
This filthy injury, be set off with madness?

sp.speaker: 1 Gen.
sp.l: Nay take your own blood's council sir, hereafter,
I'll deal no further in't: if you remember,
It was not come to blows, when I advised you.

sp.speaker: Soldier
sp.l: No, but I ever said, 'twould come to something,
And 'tis upon me, thank him: were he kin
To all the mighty emperors upon earth,
He has not now in life three hours to reckon;
I watch but a free time.

sp.speaker: 1 Gen.
sp.p: Your noble brother, sir, I'll leave you now. Ex.

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: Soldier I would I could persuade my thoughts
From thinking thee a brother, as I can
My tongue from naming on't: thou hast no friend here,
But fortune and thy own strength, trust to them.

sp.speaker: Soldier
sp.l: How? what's the incitement, sir?

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: Treachery to virtue;
Thy treachery, thy faithless circumvention:
Has honour so few daughters, never fewer,
And must thou aim thy treachery at the best?
The very front of virtue? that blessed lady? the Duke's sister?
Created more for admirations cause,
Then for loves ends; whose excellency sparkles
More in divinity, then mortal beauty;
And as much difference 'twixt her mind and body,
As 'twixt this earth's poor centre and the sun:
And couldst thou be so injurious to fair goodness,
Once to attempt to court her down to frailty?
Or put her but in mind that there is weakness,
Sin, and desire, which she should never hear of?
Wretch, thou'st committed worse than sacrilege,
In the attempting on't, and oughtst to die for't.

sp.speaker: Soldier
sp.l: I rather ought to do my best, to live, sir;
Provoke me not; for I've a wrong sits on me,
That makes me apt for mischief; I shall lose
All respects suddenly of friendship, brotherhood,
Or any sound that way.

sp.speaker: Sham.
sp.l: But 'Ware me most;
For I come with a two-edged injury;
Both my disgrace, and thy apparent falsehood,
Which must be dangerous.

sp.speaker: Soldier
sp.l: I courted her, sir:
Love starve me with delays when I confess it not.

sp.speaker: Sham.
sp.l: There's nothing then but death
Can be a penance fit for that confession.

sp.speaker: Soldier
sp.l: But far from any vicious taint.

sp.speaker: Sham.
sp.l: O sir,
Vice is a mighty stranger grown to courtship.

sp.speaker: Soldier
sp.l: Nay then the fury of my wrong light on thee.

sp.speaker: 1 Gen.
sp.l: Forbear, the duke's at hand.
Here, hard at hand, upon my reputation.

sp.speaker: Soldier
sp.l: I must do something now. Ex. soldier.

sp.speaker: Sham.
sp.l: I'll follow you close sir.

sp.speaker: 1 Gen.
sp.l: We must entreat you must not; for the Duke
Desires some conference with you.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: Let me go,
As you're gentlemen.

sp.speaker: 2 gent.
sp.l: Faith we dare not sir.

sp.speaker: Sham.
sp.l: Dare ye be false to honour, and yet dare not
Do a man justice? give me leave —

sp.speaker: 1 gent.
sp.l: Good sweet sir.
Has sent twice for you.

sp.speaker: Sham.
sp.l: Is this brave, or manly?

sp.speaker: 1 gent.
sp.l: I prithee be conformed.

sp.speaker: Sham.
sp.l: 'Death —Enter Duke.

sp.speaker: 2 gent.
sp.l: Peace, he's come introth.

sp.speaker: Sham.
sp.l: O have you betrayed me to my shame afresh?
How am I bound to loathe you?

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Shamont, welcome,
I sent twice.

sp.speaker: 2 gent.
sp.l: But my lord, he never heard on't.

sp.speaker: Sham.
sp.l: Pray pardon him, for his falseness, I did sir,
Both times; I'd rather be found rude then faithless.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: I love that bluntness dearly: has no vice,
But is more manly than some others virtue,
That lets it out only for show or profit.

sp.speaker: Sham.
sp.l: Wil't please you quit me sir, I've urgent business?

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Come, you're so hasty now: I sent for you
To a better end.

sp.speaker: Sham.
sp.l: And if it be an end,
Better or worse, I thank your goodness for't.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: I've ever kept that bounty in condition,
And thankfulness in blood, which well becomes
Both prince and subject, that where any wrong
Bears my impression, or the hasty figure
Of my repent anger, I'm a law
E'en to myself, and doom myself most strictly
To justice, and a noble satisfaction:
So that, what you in tenderness of honour,
Conceive to be loss to you, which is nothing
But curious opinion, I'll restore again,
Although I give you the best part of Genoa,
And take to boot but thanks for your amends.

sp.speaker: Sham.
sp.l: O miserable satisfaction,
Ten times more wretched than the wrong itself;
Never was ill better made good with worse:
Shall it be said that my posterity
Shall live the sole heirs of their father's shame?
And raise their wealth and glory from my stripes?
You have provided nobly bounteous sir,
For my disgrace, to make it live for ever,
Outlasting brass or marble:
This is my fear's construction, and a deep one,
Which neither argument nor time can alter:
Yet I durst swear, I wrong your goodness in't sir,
And the most fair intent on't, which I reverence
With admiration, that in you a prince,
Should be so sweet and temperate a condition,
To offer to restore where you may ruin,
And do't with justice, and in me a servant,
So harsh a disposition, that I cannot
Forgive where I should honour, and am bound to't.
But I have ever had that curiosity
In blood, and tenderness of reputation,
Such an antipathy against a blow,
I cannot speak the rest: good sir discharge me,
It is not fit that I should serve you more,
Nor come so near you; I'm made now for privacy,
And a retired condition, that's my suit,
To part from court for ever, my last suit.
And as you profess bounty, grant me that, sir.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: I would deny thee nothing.

sp.speaker: Sham.
sp.l: Health reward you; sir. Exit.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: He's gone again already, and takes hold
Of any opportunity, not riches
Can purchase him, nor honours, peaceably,
And force were brutish: what a great worth's gone with him,
And but a gentleman? well, for his sake,
I'll ne'er offend more those I cannot make:
They were his words, and shall be dear to memory.
Say I desire to see him once again;
Yet stay, he's so well forward of his peace,
'Twere pity to disturb him: he would groan
Like a soul fetched again; and that were injury,
And I've wronged his degree too much already.
Call forth the gentlemen of our chamber instantly.

sp.speaker: 1 serv.
sp.l: I shall my lord. Within.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: I may forget again,
And therefore will prevent: the strain of this
Troubles me so, one would not hazard more:

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Your will my lord?

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Yes; I discharge you all.

sp.speaker: 2 gent.
sp.l: My lord —

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Your places shall be otherwise disposed of.

sp.speaker: 4 gent.
sp.l: Why sir?

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Reply not, I dismiss you all:
You're gentlemen, your worths will find you fortunes;
Nor shall your farewell tax me of ingratitude,
I'll give you all noble remembrances,
As testimonies 'gainst reproach and malice,
That you departed loved.

sp.speaker: 3 Gen.
sp.l: This is most strange, sir.

sp.speaker: 1 Gen.
sp.l: But how is your grace furnished, these dismissed?

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Seek me out grooms.
Men more insensible of reputation,
Less curious and precise in terms of honour,
That if my anger chance let fall a stroke,
As we are all subject to impetuous passions,
Yet it may pass unmurmured, undisputed,
And not with braver fury prosecuted. Exit.

sp.speaker: 1 Gen.
sp.l: It shall be done, my lord.

sp.speaker: 3 Gen.
sp.l: Know you the cause sir?

sp.speaker: 1 Gen.
sp.l: Not I kind gentlemen, but by conjectures,
And so much shall be yours, when you please.
Thanks sir.

sp.speaker: 3 Gen.
sp.l: We shall ith' mean time think ourselves guilty
Of some foul fault, through ignorance committed.

sp.speaker: 1 Gen.
sp.l: No, 'tis not that, nor that way.

sp.speaker: 4 Gen.
sp.l: For my part.
I shall be disinherited, I knew so much.

sp.speaker: 1 Gen.
sp.l: Why sir, for what?

sp.speaker: 4 Gen.
sp.l: My sire's of a strange humour,
He'll form faults for me, and then swear 'em mine,
And commonly the first begins with lechery.
He knows his own youth's trespass.

sp.speaker: 1 Gen.
sp.l: Before you go,
I'll come and take my leave, and tell you all sirs.

sp.speaker: 3 Gen.
sp.l: Thou were't ever just and kind. Exit.

sp.speaker: 1 Gen.
sp.l: That's my poor virtue sir,
And parcel valiant; but it's hard to be perfect:
The chusing of these fellows now will puzzle me,
Horribly puzzle me; and there's no judgement,
Goes true upon man's outside, there's the mischief:
He must be touched, and tried, for gold or dross;
There is no other way for't, and that's dangerous too;
But since I'm put in trust, I will attempt it:
The Duke shall keep one daring man about him:Enter a gallant
Soft, who comes here? A pretty bravery this:
Every one goes so like a gentleman,
'Tis hard to find a difference, but byth' touch.
I'll try your mettle sure.

sp.speaker: Gallant
sp.l: Why what do you mean sir?

sp.speaker: 1 Gen.
sp.l: Nay, and you understand it not, I do not.

sp.speaker: Gallant
sp.l: Yes, would you should well know,
I understand it for a box o'th' ear sir.

sp.speaker: 1 gent.
sp.l: And of my troth, that's all I gave it for.

sp.speaker: Gallant
sp.l: 'Twere best it be so.

sp.speaker: 1 Gen.
sp.l: This is a brave coward,
A jolly threatening coward; he shall be captain:
Sir, let me meet you an hour hence i'th' lobby.

sp.speaker: Gallant
sp.l: Meet you? the world might laugh at me then i'faith.

sp.speaker: 1 Ge.
sp.l: Lay by your scorn and pride, they're scurvy qualities,
And meet me, or I'll hox you while I have you,
And carry you gambreled thither like a mutton.

sp.speaker: Gallant
sp.l: Nay, and you be in earnest, here's my hand
I will not fail you.

sp.speaker: 1 Gen.
sp.l: 'Tis for your own good.

sp.speaker: Gallant
sp.l: Away.

sp.speaker: 1 gent.
sp.l: Too much for your own good, sir, a pox on you.

sp.speaker: Gallant
sp.l: I prithee curse me all day long so.

sp.speaker: 1 Gen.
sp.l: Hang you.

sp.speaker: Gallant
sp.l: I'll make him mad; he's loath to curse too much to me;
Indeed I never yet took box oth' ear,
But it redounded, I must needs say so —

sp.speaker: 1 gent.
sp.l: Will you be gone?

sp.speaker: Gallant
sp.l: Curse, curse, and then I go.
Look how he grins, I've angered him toth' kidneys. Ex.

sp.speaker: 1 Gen.
sp.l: Was ever such a prigging coxcomb seen?
One might have beat him dumb now in this humour,
And he'd ha' grinned it out still:Enter a plain fellow.
O here's one made to my hand,
Methinks looks like a craven;
Less pains will serve his trial: some slight justle.

sp.speaker: Pl. f.
sp.l: How? take you that sir:
And if that content you not —

sp.speaker: 1 Gen.
sp.l: Yes very well sir, I desire no more.

sp.speaker: Pl. f.
sp.l: I think you need not;
For you have not lost by't. Exit.

sp.speaker: 1 Gen.
sp.l: Who would ha' thought this would have proved a gentleman?
I'll never trust long chins and little legs again,
I'll know 'em sure for gentlemen hereafter:
A gristle but in show, but gave his cuff
With such a fetch, and reach of gentry,
As if he'd had his arms before the flood;
I have taken a villainous hard task upon me;
Now I begin to have a feeling on't.
sp.stage: Enter Lapet, and clown his servant, and so habited.
sp.l: O here comes a tried piece, now, the reformed kick.
The millions of punches, spurns, and nips
That he has endured? his buttock's all black lead,
He is half a negro backward; he was passed a Spaniard
In eighty eight, and more egyptian-like;
His table and his book come both out shortly,
And all the cowards in the town expect it;
So, if I fail of my full number now,
I shall be sure to find 'em at church corners,
Where Dives, and the suffering ballads hang.

sp.speaker: Lap.
sp.l: Well, since thou art of so mild a temper,
Of so meek a spirit, thou mayst live with me,
Till better times do smile on thy deserts.
I am glad I am got home again.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.l: I am happy in your service, sir,
You'll keep me from the hospital.

sp.speaker: Lap.
sp.l: So, bring me the last proof, this is corrected.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.l: Ay, you're too full of your correction, sir.

sp.speaker: Lap
sp.l: Look I have perfect books within this half hour.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.l: Yes sir.

sp.speaker: Lap.
sp.l: Bid him put all the thumps in Pica roman,
And with great tees, (You vermin) as thumps should be.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.l: Then in what letter will you have your kicks?

sp.speaker: Lap.
sp.l: All in Italica, your backward blows
All in Italica, you hermaphrodite:
When shall I teach you wit?

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.l: O let it alone,
Till you have some yourself sir.

sp.speaker: Lap.
sp.l: You mumble?

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.l: The victuals are locked up;
I'm kept from mumbling. Exit.

sp.speaker: Lap.
sp.l: He prints my blows upon pot-paper too, the rogue,
Which had been proper for some drunken pamphlet.

sp.speaker: 1 Gen.
sp.l: Monsieur Lapet? how the world rings of your sir?
Your name sounds far and near.

sp.speaker: Lap.
sp.l: A good report it bears, for an enduring name —

sp.speaker: 1 Gen.
sp.l: What luck have you sir?

sp.speaker: Lap.
sp.l: Why, what's the matter?

sp.speaker: 1 gent.
sp.l: I'm but thinking on't.
I've heard you wish this five year for a place.
Now there's one fallen, and freely without money too;
And empty yet, and yet you cannot have't.

sp.speaker: Lap.
sp.l: No? what's the reason? I'll give money for't,
Rather than go without sir.

sp.speaker: 1 Gen.
sp.l: That's not it, sir;
The troth is, there's no gentleman must have it
Either for love or money: 'tis decreed so;
I was heartily sorry when I thought upon you,
Had you not been a gentleman I had fitted you.

sp.speaker: Lap.
sp.l: Who I a gentleman? A pox I'm none, sir.

sp.speaker: 1 Gen.
sp.l: How?

sp.speaker: Lap.
sp.l: How? why did you ever think I was?

sp.speaker: 1 Gen.
sp.l: What? not a gentleman?

sp.speaker: Lap.
sp.l: I would thou'dst put it upon me i'faith.
Did not my grandfather cry coney-skins?
My father aquavitae? A hot gentleman:
All this I speak on i' your time and memory too;
Only a rich uncle died and left me chattels,
You know all this so well too —

sp.speaker: 1 Gen.
sp.l: Pray excuse me, sir, ha' not you arms?

sp.speaker: Lap.
sp.l: Yes, a poor couple here.
That serve to thrust in wildfowl.

sp.speaker: 1 Gen.
sp.l: Herald's arms,
Symbols of gentry, sir: you know my meaning;
They've been shown and seen.

sp.speaker: Lap.
sp.l: They have.

sp.speaker: 1 Gen.
sp.l: I fex have they.

sp.speaker: Lap.
sp.l: Why I confess, at my wife's instigation once,
(As women love these herald's kickshaws naturally)
I bought 'em: but what are they think you? puffs.

sp.speaker: 1 Gen.
sp.l: Why, that's proper to your name being lapet.
Which is la fart, after the English letter.

sp.speaker: Lap.
sp.l: The herald, sir, had much ado to find it.

sp.speaker: 1 Gen.
sp.l: And can you blame him?
Why 'tis the only thing that puzzles the devil.

sp.speaker: Lap.
sp.l: At last he looked upon my name again,
And having well compared it, this he gave me,
The two colics playing upon a wind instrument.

sp.speaker: 1 Gen.
sp.l: An excellent proper one: but I pray tell me,
How does he express the colics?
They are hard things.

sp.speaker: Lap.
sp.l: The colics? with hot trenchers at their bellies,
There's nothing better, sir, to blaze a colic.

sp.speaker: 1 Gen.
sp.l: And are not you a gentleman by this sir?

sp.speaker: Lap.
sp.l: No, I disclaim't: no belly-ache upon earth
Shall make me one: he shall not think
To put his gripes upon me,
And wring out gentry so, and ten pound first.
If the wind instrument will make my wife one,
Let her enjoy't, for she was a harper's grandchild:
But sir, for my particular, I renounce it.

sp.speaker: 1 Gen.
sp.l: Or to be called so?

sp.speaker: Lap.
sp.l: Ay sir, or imagined.

sp.speaker: 1 Gen.
sp.l: None fitter for the place: give me thy hand.

sp.speaker: Lap.
sp.l: A hundred thousand thanks, beside a bribe sir.

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.l: You must take heed
Of thinking towards a gentleman, now.

sp.speaker: Lap.
sp.l: Pish, I am not mad, I warrant you: nay more sir,
If one should twit me i'th' teeth that I'm a gentleman,
Twit me their worst, I am but one since Lammas,
That I can prove, if they would see my heart out.

sp.speaker: 1 Gen.
sp.l: Marry in any case keep me that evidence.

sp.speaker: Lap.
sp.l: Here comes my servant, sir, Galoshio,
Has not his name for naught, he will be trod upon:
What says my printer now?

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.l: Here's your last proof sir.
You shall have perfect books now in a twinkling.

sp.speaker: Lap.
sp.l: These marks are ugly.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.l: He says, sir, they're proper:
Blows should have marks, or else they are nothing worth.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: But why a peel-crow here?

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.l: I told 'em so sir:
A scarecrow had been better.

sp.speaker: Lap.
sp.l: How slave? look you sir,
Did not I say, this wherret, and this bob,
Should be both Pica roman.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.l: So said I sir, both picked Romans,
And he has made 'em Welch bills,
Indeed I know not what to make on 'em.

sp.speaker: Lap.
sp.l: Hay-day; a souse, Italica?

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.l: Yes, that may hold sir,
Souse is a bonaroba, so is flops too.

sp.speaker: Lap.
sp.l: But why stands bastinado so far off here?

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.l: Alas you must allow him room to lay about him, sir.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Why lies this spurn lower than that spurn, sir?

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.l: Marry this signifies one kicked down stairs, sir,
The other in a gallery: I asked him all these questions.

sp.speaker: 1 Gen.
sp.l: Your books name?
Prithee Lapet mind me, you never told me yet.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Marry but shall sir: 'tis called the uprising of the kick,
And the downfall of the duello.

sp.speaker: 1 Gen.
sp.l: Bring that to pass you'll prove a happy member,
And do your country service: your young bloods
Will thank you then, when they see fourscore.

sp.speaker: Lap.
sp.l: I hope
To save my hundred gentlemen a month by't,
Which will be very good for the private house.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.l: Look you, your table's finished sir already.

sp.speaker: Lap.
sp.l: Why then behold my masterpiece: see, see, sir,
Here's all your blows, and blow-men whatsoever,
Set in their lively colours, givers, and takers.

sp.speaker: 1 Gen.
sp.l: Troth wondrous fine, sir.

sp.speaker: Lap.
sp.l: Nay, but mark the postures,
The standing of the takers I admire more than the givers,
They stand scornfully, most contumeliously, I like not them,
O here's one cast into a comely figure.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.l: My master means him there that's cast down headlong.

sp.speaker: Lap.
sp.l: How sweetly does this fellow take his Dowst?
Stoops like a camel, that heroic beast,
At a great load of nutmegs; and how meekly
This other fellow here receives his wherret?

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.l: O master here's a fellow stands most gallantly,
Taking his kick in private behind the hangings,
And raising up his hips to't. But o, sir,
How daintily this man lies trampled on?
Would I were in thy place, whate'er thou art:
How lovely he endures it?

sp.speaker: 1 Gen.
sp.p: But will not these things, sir, be hard to practise, think you?

sp.speaker: Lap.
sp.l: O, easy, sir: I'll teach 'em in a dance.

sp.speaker: 1 gent.
sp.l: How? in a dance?

sp.speaker: Lap.
sp.l: I'll lose my new place else,
Whate'er it be; I know not what 'tis yet.

sp.speaker: 1 Gen.
sp.l: And now you put me in mind, I could employ it well,
For your grace, specially: for the Duke's cozen
Is by this time in's violent fit of mirth,
And a device must be sought out for suddenly,
To overcloy the passion.

sp.speaker: Lap.
sp.l: Say no more, sir,
I'll fit you with my scholars, new practitioners,
Endurers of the time.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.l: Whereof I am one sir.

sp.speaker: 1 Gen.
sp.l: You carry it away smooth; give me thy hand, sir.

div.head: Scaena prima.

sp.speaker: Passionate
sp.l: Ha, ha, ha. Within.

sp.speaker: 2 Bro.
sp.l: Hark, hark, how loud his fit's grown.

sp.speaker: Passionate
sp.l: Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: 1. Bro.
sp.l: Now let our sister lose no time, but ply it
With all the power she has.

sp.speaker: 2 Bro.
sp.l: Her shame grows big, brother;
The Cupids shape will hardly hold it longer,
'Twould take up half an ell of China damask more,
And all too little: it struts per'lously:
There is no tampering with these Cupids longer,
The mere conceit with womankind works strong.

sp.speaker: Passionate
sp.l: Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: 2 Bro.
sp.l: The laugh comes nearer now,
'Twere good we were not seen yet. Ex. Broth.

div.stage: Enter passion. and base his jester.

sp.speaker: Passionate
sp.l: Ha, ha, ha.
And was he bastinadoed to the life? ha, ha, ha.
I prithee say, lord general, how did the rascals
Entrench themselves?

sp.speaker: Base
sp.l: Most deeply, politicly, all in ditches.

sp.speaker: Passionate
sp.l: Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Bas.
sp.l: 'Tis thought he'll never bear arms ith' field again,
Has much ado, to lift 'em to his head, sir.

sp.speaker: Passionate
sp.l: I would he had.

sp.speaker: Base
sp.l: On either side round truncheons played so thick,
That shoulders, chines, nay flanks were paid toth' quick.

sp.speaker: Passionate
sp.l: Well said lord general: ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Bas.
sp.l: But pray how grew the difference first betwixt you?

sp.speaker: Passionate
sp.l: There was never any sir; there lies the jest man;
Only because he was taller than his brother;
There's all my quarrel to him; and methought
He should be beaten for't, my mind so gave me, sir,
I could not sleep for't; ha, ha, ha, ha.
Another good jest quickly, while 'tis hot now;
Let me not laugh in vain: ply me, oh ply me,
As you will answer't to my cousin Duke.

sp.speaker: Bas.
sp.l: Alas, who has a good jest?

sp.speaker: Passionate
sp.l: I fall, I dwindle in't.

sp.speaker: Bas.
sp.l: Ten crowns for a good jest: ha' you a good jest, sir?

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.l: A pretty moral one.

sp.speaker: Bas.
sp.l: Let's have't, whate'er it be.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: There comes a Cupid
Drawn by six fools.

sp.speaker: Bas.
sp.l: That's nothing.

sp.speaker: Passionate
sp.l: Help it, help it then.

sp.speaker: Bas.
sp.l: I ha' known six hundred fools drawn by a Cupid.

sp.speaker: Passionate
sp.l: I that, that, that's the smarter moral: ha, ha, ha.
Now I begin to be song-ripe methinks.

sp.speaker: Bas.
sp.l: I'll sing you a pleasant air, sir, before you ebb.

sp.speaker: Passionate
sp.l: O how my lungs do tickle? ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Bas.
sp.l: O how my lungs do tickle? o, o, ho, ho.

sp.speaker: Passionate
sp.l: Set a sharp jest
Against my breast,
Then how my lungs do tickle?
As nightingales,
And things in cambric rails,
Sing best against a prickle.
Ha, ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Bas.
sp.l: Ho, ho, ho, ho, ha.

sp.speaker: Passionate
sp.l: Laugh.

sp.speaker: Bas.
sp.l: Laugh.

sp.speaker: Passionate
sp.l: Laugh.

sp.speaker: Bas.
sp.l: Laugh.

sp.speaker: Passionate
sp.l: Wide.

sp.speaker: Bas.
sp.l: Loud.

sp.speaker: Passionate
sp.l: And vary.

sp.speaker: Bas.
sp.l: A smile is for a simpering novice.

sp.speaker: Passionate
sp.l: One that never tasted caviar,

sp.speaker: Bas.
sp.l: Nor knows the smack of dear Anchovis.

sp.speaker: Passionate
sp.l: Ha, ha, ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Bas.
sp.l: Ho, ho, ho, ho, ho.

sp.speaker: Passionate
sp.l: A giggling waiting wench for me,
That shows her teeth how white they be.

sp.speaker: Bas.
